data.title: Revolution and Reaction - A (very) French Victoria II Interactive AAR
data.meta_description: Salutations et bienvenue  Revolution and Reaction, a Victoria II Interactive AAR with the Concert of Europe II: Gloria Mod. For those participants of my...
data.text:
He Came Home

How do you find it? Philippe asked, as he and his wife had now walked for some time around the gardens of Chantilly. This was his home, his country estate, the legacy of his family and the place which he longed to return to; sadly once again he was only here for the weekend. It was not that the place had fallen into neglect, Philippe had been sure to prevent that, but there was not quite the same joy as once he departed. Though much of that may also have been in Philippes mind as he at times felt he had abandoned his project.

Its beautiful. And his wife did truly think it, Though it lacks more substance inside. A fact which was not wrong, as the election and running of France after it, had taken up most of Philippes time. In the past the young aristocrat would have gone to art auctions, sales and galleries, but that had not been the case for some time. A bit remote.

Think you will come to miss Paris? Philippe asked Florestine, as she had been used to the city ever since their marriage, but Philippe had come to grow distasteful of it once more. It had in truth been one of the primary reasons for his enjoyment of Saint-Cloud. It was far enough outside of the city itself that Philippe could enjoy the scenery, and the distance, while his wife and he could still attend to events inside the city and her not being bored entirely to tears.

The company, I think, along with the entertainment. Florestine had made quite a few close friends while in Paris. Her social standing, despite the conflicts of her husbands regime, had produced quite marvelous contacts as people were eager as ever to carry favour and have influence. A social standing which she now, at least potentially, had to give up if Philippe once again wished to move out into the provinces. Her station was also helped by the fact that she was the rank and title of Princess of Monaco, and thus carried social influence and grace by her mere presence.

Nothing prevents them from coming out here. Which only gained Philippe a glance from his wife, which was fair considering his suggestion. There would likely be seasons yet again, just like the time of old, and many things depending upon the decisions and travel plans of his Majesty. Im meeting with the owners of the Hotels du Plessis-Bellire and Moreau on Thursday, so that we may begin discussing the price which they are willing to part with their homes for, if they are willing. And luckily, Orleans as per arrangement for this restoration, and Nemours and the house of Orleans were going to pay for half of this cost, a cost which would no doubt add up to millions, if not a couple of tens of millions.

Central Paris, Place de la Concorde, large rooms with much floor space, room for occasions and plenty of social standing and parties which can be thrown in honour of the King. Florestine approved, that there was little doubt about, neither in her own mind or that of Philippe and it was prime property which they would receive. She would be able to throw banquets, balls and parties which would once again make her the center, or a center of Parisian society.

Philippe looked at Florestine for a moment, sighing slightly as he knew that she would not be entirely content, I have planned for you to stay here for the coming months. Philippe told her, and while she hid it, he could see it on her lips as they turned ever so slightly to a frown. The season begins soon, and I want Chantilly to be ready for when we host the races. Which was another one of the big reasons that Philippe had returned home this weekend, to prepare for the annual horse races. Especially as he was forced to miss the horse races last year due to his tour, a tour which now seemed rather redundant. A few friends will come to stay, and partake. And who knew, perhaps the King would even come at some point, either for the races or far more likely, for the forests. The King was a renown hunter, eagerly partaking in the hunt whenever possible, or so it was said and Chantilly had been a favorite ground of all those who came before him, so perhaps the same would happen now. It would surely fit Philippe should it come to pass, as there were always more than one to royal favour and influence, but that time still slept, and the horse races did not, and neither would the Kings promise for long, hopefully. Henri would have time to carry out the promise made by Charlus before Philippe would begin to push for it. There was a time and a place for everything, and if the last two years had proven anything to Philippe, that was it, but as he had also learned, that would only be allowed for so long.

How many months? Florestine asked, putting on a minor smile for Philippe as she began looking out over the artificial lake, and the trees behind it.

Until I join you? Philippe then asked her, he knew the truth already, Three at most and I promise to come as often as I can. Which was no lie, he now served as President of the Council of State, and position which he in truth had little to no desire to hold. Had the King not asked him to serve, he would certainly not have asked for it. It was troublesome to control and manage his own council, but now there was not only another master above Philippe, but all were responsible to the King and not to Philippe and thus, his authority would only be what the King wished. It was not a desirable position, especially as he would likely be blamed, blamed for actions which he now likely would have far more limited control over and yet still receive the blame. I believe the King will appoint a new cabinet after the election, if he still asks me to serve, then so be it, but I want to come home, I am tired of living at Lassay at the grace of Amlie and Louis. Making the former President sigh, If I like our new home, maybe, but I dont know, dear. He said truthfully as he took her arm, offering a weakened smile as they kept walking.

------------------------------------------------

Election of Deputies: Centre-Gauche (blues-sombre and republican rallies).

[Morning Star: +2,5PP]

[Oise]

Mmoires d'un Royaliste

Audiences at the Palace

(Co-Written with @Maxwell500)



I began to grow into a regimented routine, and rose and fell each day with the same busy rhythm. We knew the King would take mass at 7 AM and then again two hours later; his routine allowed the Comtesse and I plenty of time to schedule ourselves according to his movements. I would dress with a light breakfast, take my leave from the Htel de Galliffet, and hasten down to the Egalise Saint Thomas d'Aquin by carriage, where I would enjoy my mass with proximity to the Palace. After the service, I returned to my vehicle and passed over the Pont Royal, whereupon attendants, by now familiar with my repetitive attendances, took care of my driver and horse.

In the early days, the Palace was terribly chaotic; provincial noblemen waited to press for compensations of old privileges, ambitious young gentlemen fawned and praised, and ecclesiastics of all shades scuffled out as quickly as they had passed in. There were endless reports from the provinces, from the ambassadors, and from the field officers. The whole scene seemed ephemeral; I found order more clarified as I drew closer to the offices of the King. By this point he was no doubt engaged with his ministers, and on more than one occasion I stumbled across the Comte de La Marche, a man who owned a complicated path. We disliked each other, that much was perfectly clear, but circumstance had forced our cooperation, and for the moment our relations were excellent.

I was not in receipt of any official office, and my presence before the King was always offered in the style one might expect from a courtier. I was not even a member of his maison civile. To that intimate group belonged the Comte de Monti de Rez, Comte Fernand de La Ferronnays, the Marquis de la Fert-Meun, the Marquis de Foresta, Comte Maxence de Damas, the Comte de Neuville, Comte de Blacas, Comte de Chevign, M. Chapot, the Comte de Belleval, and the Vicomte de Saint-Priest. I had long belived they were here for gifts, and Chambord had proven inflexible, holding that the King must be on his throne before granting such possessions; now he dared to show his generosity. There was also the maison pay, and generally the clergymen were here in abundance. There was first the Abbe Bol, who hated the Orlans family, Doctor Carriere, a noted liberal, M. Moricet, the secretary of the King, a rather pathetic little thing, and his subsecretary, M. Huet de Pavillon.

It was a curious royal household, and it was held together, first by Providence, and then by my father, Monsieur le Duc de Lvis. Officially my attendances with the King were held ancillary to that of my father; unofficially my presence was necessary as the undesirious leader of the legitimist party. The King always greeted me with the utmost affection, certainly more so than my father, who was haughty and cold. He was, however, a well placed adviser, extremely intimate with the king (he called the Prince by the informal "vous,") and merited his position; he more than one told me: "When you serve a prince, never forget that all which is good has been done by him, and all that is bad you have done." I kept these solemn words close.

I have recounted an excerpt from a longer conversation, one held early in his reign, over certain appointments to high office. This particular audience was held in his study, which he declared to be the same space used by Louis XVIII.

"And there is the question of M. Merive," interceded my father.

"We had discussed a diplomatic post?" responded the King, as he then turned to me. I saw it was my reply.

"You know my opinion of him, Sire." I replied. My quarrels with Merive were well-known; I believed that he had repaid my renewed introductions to politics with poor discretion and indiscipline, although my temper had cooled, and I could not deny his value.

"My son reflects too harshly," Lvis told the King.

"He tends to exaggerate," laughed the King. I accepted these little asides at my expense. "No, he has paid good serve to the crown, in spite of past inadequacies."

"I would not dispute that, Monseigneur." I answered. "But I think his temperament, conditions granted, would not suit us well."

Lvis glanced up, and made clear by his stare that he wished me to delicately offer a plan previously discussed between father and son.

"Perhaps it would be best to give him honors commensurate to his service?" I started with a small and innocent query.

"Yes, and he is also the son-in-law of our dear and late Montmorency-Laval," continued Lvis; he had never lost his sincere affection for the old duke.

The King arrived at the desired conclusion. "I would see no reason, when the list is drawn, to deny him a peerage well deserved." My father and I gave murmurs of approval, and the matter was settled there.

We next proceeded to issues reviewing the situation of the ministry, and agreed that it would be best to keep this republican remnant until the country was settled. On this topic I was silent, as I found myself eager to disengage on the interior politics.

"And Monsieur le Comte is still resolved to Rome?" asked the King.

"Yes."

"It will be an inconvenient loss," prodded my father.

"I would not wish to inconvenience you, Monseigneur, but I cannot shake my conviction that my energies would be best restoring the nation to her desired status as elder daughter of the Church."

"I will reflect on this further, and take your desires into consideration. But for now, I reserve my judgement." The matter thus delayed on the King's wish, we made various recommendations on ambassadorial roles.

It was suggested that Monsieur le Duc de Gramont be sent to England and the Comte de Rayneval to Austria. These two were easy propositions; they were from diplomatic families with noted and previous experience in those countries. Next, it was decided a firm legitimist would need to be dispatched to Russia to assure the Tsar of our fidelity. I recommended that the Duc de Mortemart, who had previously served in that capacity during the Restoration, resume the position.

The incumbent ambassador to England, douard Drouyn de Lhuys, who had become somewhat hostile to the previous government, was considered for Madrid, where he had served during the June Monarchy with distinction. Another devoted servant from the corps diplomatique, Baron douard Burignot de Varenne, who was the son of a royalist diplomat, and himself an experienced ambassador, was offered praise, and I advised his elevation in Prussia. A diplomatic position was also sought for the Marquis de Moustier, an official who we may say was imbued with perfect credentials for the service, and this my father offered to the King.



The discussions continued for at least an hour, and when they were completed, and the proposals submitted for the consideration of the King, I took my leave, and hastened back to continue my normal duties in the Assembly. This custom was repeated without break for the duration of the legislative session, and the subsequent recess.





A Lonely Night with Wine

Philippes head had begun pounding about an hour ago as the headache took further hold. The night had long since taken hold outside, with the moon shining proud outside his window as the candles burned, both in front of the former President on his desk, but also around the room in the edges and corners which the fireplace did not quite reach. The very bane and blessing of France had become his this night, that being the very bane of the French agriculture, the very core of much of the French economy. It had become his bane, as it kept him up well past midnight, as the darkness of night had long since consumed the sun. But it had also become his blessing, as the very same agriculture had produced the very wine which he had just finished another glass of.

Philippe had spent his time analyzing the conclusion of the commission which was put in place during the government, in large part thanks to the excessive eagerness of his agricultural minister. Along with this committee came the problem of past laws, new charters and the Napoleonic code. Alone, each part may be beneficial or helpful, but as a whole they proved a dangerous drink, filled with poison which was crippling French agriculture, at least it was so in Philippes mind, though part of that may also have been the wine.

The main issue that Philippe concluded, at least with his own fantastical opinions, was simply that far too many people owned land. Too many people had become tied to the land, stemming all the way back to the Napoleonic Code. As the Code itself was built on equality, so was the inheritance laws, and with each single inheritance the problem only became worse as every farm was made smaller and split between sons. The only way to prevent this was for the individual sons to forsake their inheritance in favour of one of their brothers, which anyone who has had family and a dispute with money, would find a laughable idea. Yet this wasnt the issue which a solution eluded Philippe, for he had already written up a law in regards to inheritance, one which he had planned to present during the Republic yet never came to pass.

No that issue would be solved, so that farms could remain together without the constant issue of fracture. The far bigger issues to solve would be on how to merge many of these smaller farms into greater ones. Many farms were no greater than around two acres, far too little to support or supply a family, a problem which would persist. Philippes Minister of Agriculture, Auberjonois, had come with his own suggestion, in large part based off of the idea of the communal cooperatives. His ideas werent without base, for if proven true it would mean that the farmers would indeed be allowed to receive new credit, thus being able to modernize. Yet this solution would also only be half useful, as it left the core of the issue the same. Now while the farms would be larger, it would not increase the amount of land individually owned, and the land still had to provide for an equal amount of families.

The Provisional Government had given their attempts, with their communal land, to improve the lot of life for many families. A noble goal, no doubt, but all the same Philippe felt they had gone about it in a wrong way. A though which only resulted in him drowning another glass of wine as he considered how to dissolve the communal land cooperatives. A far better solution than giving everyone land, at least to Philippes mind, would have been to establish farms of twenty acres, perhaps more or less, but large farms all the same for select families, who could then use them for long term investment while owning a farm large enough to support themselves and see prosperity. Yet it had not come to pass.

Instead, even more people had become tied to the land, many tied to land with small farms unable to support their families. The charter made the confiscation of property a near impossibility, and rightfully so, but it did complicate these matters somewhat. The small farms needed to be unified, not just in cooperatives, but under a single individual so that they can provide for a family, rather than ten families being provided for by twenty acres.

Philippes headache only grew worse as he drowned the last glass, having grown tired with the issue for the night and rose up from his chair, stretching for a moment as a nice feeling of calm came over his body and it hit him. Perhaps the way forward would be as simple as ensuring credit for medium farms to buy the smaller ones next to them, thereby growing them while eliminating the small ones. A small smile began spreading across his lips, he would need to look into it when he woke up, but had he actually found a solution, or would he simply look like a fool come the morning. Not that he had enough time to consider the issue as he found the bed in the rooms which he had rented in Paris, and collapsed in the a deep slumber lasting many hours.
